results.adx_keywords: Abortion;Law and Legislation;United States Politics and Government;Midterm Elections (2022);Graham, Lindsey;Republican Party
results.title: Graham Proposes 15-Week Abortion Ban, Splitting Republicans
results.abstract: The South Carolina senator’s bill was an effort to find a politically palatable position for his party before the midterm elections, in which abortion rights are expected to be a potent issue.

media.caption: Senator Lindsey Graham’s proposal was an effort to politically insulate Republicans from voter backlash after a Supreme Court ruling in June ended the constitutional right to abortion.

results.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Maggie Haberman, Adam Goldman and Alan Feuer
results.title: Justice Dept. Issues 40 Subpoenas in a Week, Expanding Its Jan. 6 Inquiry
results.abstract: It also seized the phones of two top Trump advisers, a sign of an escalating investigation two months before the midterm elections.

media.caption: The mob at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The Justice Department has spent more than a year focused on investigating rioters at the Capitol but has more recently been issuing subpoenas to figures closer to former President Donald J. Trump.
media.copyright: Jason Andrew for The New York Times

results.byline: By Dave Kehr and Jonathan Kandell
results.title: Jean-Luc Godard, 91, Is Dead; Bold Director Shaped French New Wave
results.abstract: The Franco-Swiss filmmaker and provocateur radically rethought motion pictures and left a lasting influence on the medium.

media.caption: Jean-Luc Godard in 1964. “I have always confused cinema with life,” he said. “To me life is just part of films.”

results.adx_keywords: Bees;Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain;Great Britain
results.title: When the Queen Died, Someone Had to Tell the Bees
results.abstract: A report that the royal beekeeper had informed Queen Elizabeth II’s bees of her death received some mockery, but it has been a tradition for centuries.
per_facet: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

media.caption: “Der Bienenfreund” (“The Bee Friend”), an 1863 painting by the German artist Hans Thoma. “Telling the bees” is a custom practiced in Britain and other parts of Europe.

results.title: U.S. News Dropped Columbia’s Ranking, but Its Own Methods Are Now Questioned
results.abstract: After doubt about its data, the university dropped to No. 18 from No. 2. But now many are asking, can the rating system be that easily manipulated?

media.caption: On Friday, Columbia said some of its data was using outdated or incorrect methodologies.

results.title: Father Says He Sought Custody Before 3 Children Drowned in Brooklyn

results.adx_keywords: Archaeology and Anthropology;Mayans;your-feed-science;Golden, Charles W;Scherer, Andrew K;Brandeis University;Brown University;Chiapas (Mexico);Guatemala;Mesoamerica
results.byline: By Franz Lidz and Meghan Dhaliwal
results.title: Unearthing a Maya Civilization That ‘Punched Above Its Weight’
results.abstract: Before the pandemic, the long-sought ruins of Sak Tz’i’, a small but influential Mesoamerican kingdom, were discovered on a cattle ranch in Mexico. This summer archaeologists returned to excavate it.

media.caption: A stone panel, dating to the eighth century A.D., of K’ab Kante’, a ruler of the ancient Maya kingdom of Sak Tz’i’. The ruins of Lakanjá Tzeltal, a settlement at least 2,500 years old, were discovered in Chiapas, Mexico.
media.copyright: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Sex Crimes;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Police;Law and Legislation;Police Department (San Francisco, Calif);San Francisco (Calif);California
results.title: Woman Sues San Francisco Over Arrest Based on DNA From Her Rape Kit
results.abstract: The woman had provided her DNA to police after being sexually assaulted in 2016, her lawyer said. About five years later, officers used it to charge her with retail theft.

media.caption: Chesa Boudin, then the San Francisco district attorney, declined to prosecute the woman. At a news conference in February, Mr. Boudin said victims of sexual assault had been treated “like evidence, not human beings.”
